Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the grant, the PI will study topology of 3-manifolds in terms their fundamental groups. The research will be based on recent progress in the Virtual Fibration Conjecture and the Virtual Haken Conjecture. Ingredients about surface subsubgroups in 3-manifolds will be summarized and generalized, and will be applied to approach existing problems including the virtual positivity of representation volumes and the linearity of 3-manifold groups. The project will also study the virtual properties of surface automorphisms. This is closely related to the surface bundle case of Virtual Homological Torsion Conjecture. The PI proposes to apply methods from geometric group theory, dynamical systems, representation theory, and low dimension topology.

Spaces and transformations provide an important perspective on mathematically modelling our world. Natural sciences and certain social sciences utilize them as abstract tools to understand symmetry of various systems. The PI will study geometric transformations on 3-dimensional spaces, which form an essential family for many applications involved in physics, computer sciences, and other disciplines. This family of transformations have been proved to be powerful and mathematically comprehensible, thanks to recent solutions of long existing conjectures. The principal pursuit of this project is to attack several existing problems in low dimensional topology with the new techniques. Besides, the project endeavors to theoretically summarize recent development of the area, making the new ideas more accessible to working scientists from all disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studies 3-dimensional manifolds and properties of their finite covers. In 3-dimensional topology and geometry, one of the most remarkable achievements accomplished during the past few years is the resolution of W. P. Thurston's Virtual Haken Conjecture and Virtual Fibering Conjecture. Two major ingredients involved in I. Agol's proof are the Surface Subgroup Theorem due J. Kahn and V. Markovic and the theory of virtual special cubulation due to D. Wise et al. The project continues the development in those two directions and considers the extension of those techniques to more general situations.


Under the support of this project, the PI works with Markovic to extend the Kahn--Markovic construction. The new construction produces immersed bounded subsurfaces in any closed hyperbolic 3-manifold with prescribed good boundary and prescribed relative homology class. The resulting subsurfaces have very nice geometric properties (nearly totally geodesic) so they give rise to injective homomorphisms of their fundamental groups. Moreover, the homologically interesting bounded construction can be combined with known constructions of geometrically nice loops to produce immersed 2-complexes that can serve various significant applications. An example of the applications is due to H. Sun, who has used the promoted construction to build nonzero degree maps from a finite cover of a closed hyperbolic 3-manifold onto any other closed orientable 3-manifold. This first part of the project also explicitly characterizes the obstruction to such constructions.


The second part of project outcomes is a completely characterization of the separability of surface subgroups in 3-manifold groups due to the PI. The topological version of the result is closely related to the problem whether an immersed subsurface can be lifted (and contiuously moved) into a finite cover of a given 3-manifold to be embedded. The PI has found that the obstruction to the existence can be precisely described by a homological class associated with the immersion, which is called the spirality character. Using the new invariant, the PI shows that many nongeometric 3-manifold contains immersed subsurfaces that are not virtually embedded. In fact, the examples suggest that the phenomenon may be possible for all nongeometric 3-manifold, which is rather opposite to the geometric case.


As the third part of the project, the PI works with P. Derbez and S. Wang to study virtual representation volume of 3-manifolds. In differential topology, representation volumes are considered to be generalization to arbitrary closed oriented manifolds of those usual volumes for geometric manifolds. In the case of dimension 3, every representation of the fundamental group into the universal covering group of SL(2,R) gives rise to a real-valued volume associated to that representation, and the supremum in absolute value over all representations gives rise to an invariant of the 3-manifold called the Seifert volume. An arbitrary 3-manifold may have only vanishing Seifert volume, but the fundamental observation is that topology can be learned from Seifert volume of finite covers. In the joint work of the project, it has been confirmed that once there is a Seifert geometrical piece in the geometric decomposition of a 3-manifold, there must be a finite cover of that manifold of nonvanishing Seifert volume. A similar result also holds for the hyperbolic volume associated with those representations into PSL(2,C).

During the life of the project, the PI has presented the above works on seminars at various research institutes, and has given talks on international conferences. Those activities have enhanced communication within the academic community and increased the impact of the current project. There are several following research works posted by various authors on each of the above aspects.
